articles.headline: TikTok Deal Trips Over U.S.-China Power Struggle
articles.snippet: Companies involved in a deal to resolve TikTok’s future publicly clashed over the arrangement, while President Trump threatened to block any deal that left the service in Chinese hands.
articles.abstract: Companies involved in a deal to resolve TikTok’s future publicly clashed over the arrangement, while President Trump threatened to block any deal that left the service in Chinese hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A deal intended to address the Trump administration’s concerns about TikTok’s ties to China was complicated on Monday by a disagreement over whether a U.S. company would control the social media app and the president’s threat to block any agreement that leaves the service in the hands of a Chinese company.
articles.byline: By David McCabe, Ana Swanson and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: ‘You Would Do the Same’: Graham Is Defiant on Supreme Court Reversal
articles.snippet: Senator Lindsey Graham said he would refuse to confirm a Republican’s Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year. Now he is rushing to deliver President Trump’s third justice.
articles.abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham said he would refuse to confirm a Republican’s Supreme Court nominee in a presidential election year. Now he is rushing to deliver President Trump’s third justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Senator Lindsey Graham joined a Republican blockade of President Barack Obama’s Supreme Court nominee in 2016, he went out of his way to frame his position that a confirmation to the court should never be allowed in an election year as principled, apolitical and utterly permanent.

articles.headline: How Ginsburg’s Death Has Reshaped the Money Race for Senate Democrats
articles.snippet: From Alaska to Maine to the Carolinas, Democratic strategists working on Senate campaigns described a spontaneous outpouring of donations the likes of which they had never seen. A Republican surge is expected as well.
articles.abstract: From Alaska to Maine to the Carolinas, Democratic strategists working on Senate campaigns described a spontaneous outpouring of donations the likes of which they had never seen. A Republican surge is expected as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of 2020, Al Gross’s Senate campaign in Alaska has proceeded as something of an afterthought for most Democrats, a distant contest that was off the radar in terms of determining control of the U.S. Senate. After all, Mr. Gross is not even technically running as a Democrat, an affiliation that might doom him in a conservative state.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Republican Senators Line Up to Back Trump on Court Fight
articles.snippet: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Judiciary Committee chairman, says Republicans have the votes to confirm the president’s choice before the Nov. 3 election, though it will still be a challenge.
articles.abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Judiciary Committee chairman, says Republicans have the votes to confirm the president’s choice before the Nov. 3 election, though it will still be a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: President Trump has selected Judge Amy Coney Barrett to fill Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s seat on the Supreme Court.]
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Stakeholder Capitalism Gets a Report Card. It’s Not Good.
articles.snippet: The pandemic and the movement for racial justice have tested corporate pledges to elevate social concerns alongside shareholder interests. A new study finds companies are failing to follow through.
articles.abstract: The pandemic and the movement for racial justice have tested corporate pledges to elevate social concerns alongside shareholder interests. A new study finds companies are failing to follow through.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marc Benioff, chief executive of the technology giant Salesforce, presents himself as an evangelist for stakeholder capitalism: the idea that companies must elevate the interests of workers, the environment and local communities alongside shareholders.

articles.headline: As Schools Go Remote, Finding ‘Lost’ Students Gets Harder
articles.snippet: Early data for the new school year suggests that attendance in virtual classrooms is down, possibly because students are working or caring for siblings.
articles.abstract: Early data for the new school year suggests that attendance in virtual classrooms is down, possibly because students are working or caring for siblings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One month into the school year, Linnet Early, a social studies teacher outside St. Louis, has an anxious new ritual: scanning the Zoom squares on her computer screen at the beginning of each class to see which of her sixth-grade students are missing. It is usually quite a few.

articles.headline: He Killed 2 Marines in 2011. It Almost Derailed Peace Talks This Month.
articles.snippet: Even as they pushed for the release of other Afghan prisoners as part of a deal with the Taliban, U.S. officials privately dug in over freeing a man who had killed Americans.
articles.abstract: Even as they pushed for the release of other Afghan prisoners as part of a deal with the Taliban, U.S. officials privately dug in over freeing a man who had killed Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — He was a young Afghan police officer working alongside American forces in one of the hot spots of the war, with Taliban ambushes all around. Then he turned his weapon on two U.S. Marines, killing them both.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Can Luxury Fashion Ever Regain Its Luster?
articles.snippet: The industry is trying to reach customers amid a severe global recession that has brought mass layoffs and plunging sales. Traditional fashion weeks might be out of step.
articles.abstract: The industry is trying to reach customers amid a severe global recession that has brought mass layoffs and plunging sales. Traditional fashion weeks might be out of step.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is usually a busy month for the luxury industry. Not long after glossy fashion magazines publish their all-important September issues, thousands of retail buyers, journalists and clients embark on a tour of New York, London, Milan and Paris.
